overview: Income Support is extra money to help people on a low income - rates, eligibility and how to claim
title: Income Support

table.body:
Income Support is extra money for those on a low income, working less than 16 hours a week and who haven't signed on as unemployed. 

You could get at least £56.25 a week - the actual amount can be higher but will depend on your circumstances and what you [qualify](income-support#eligibility "Eligibility") for. 

You can claim [Child Tax Credit](/child-tax-credit "Child Tax Credit") if you claim Income Support and have children. 

^ Use the [benefits adviser](/benefit-adviser "Benefits Adviser") to work out what money you can get if you're on a low income. ^
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You get a basic payment (a 'personal allowance') and extra payments (premiums) on top of this. Your income and any savings (over £5999) can affect how much you get.

##Personal allowance

Status | Age | Weekly payment
- | -
Single | 16 to 24 | £56.25
Single | 25 or over | £71.00
Lone parent | 16 to 17 | £56.25
Lone parent |18 or over | £71.00
Couples | Both under 18 | £56.25 
Couples | One under 18, the other 18 to 24 | £56.25 
Couples | One under 18, the other 25 or over | £71.00
Couples | Both 18 or over | £111.45

##Premiums

You can get between £14.80 and £116.40 extra depending on your circumstances. For example, if you're a pensioner, [disabled](/disability-premiums-income-support "Disability premiums"), a lone parent with a disabled child. 

^Use the [benefits adviser](/benefits-adviser "Benefits adviser") to work out how much you can get.^  			

##How you're paid

All benefits, pensions and allowances are [paid into an account](/how-to-have-your-benefits-paid "How you're paid"), eg a bank account. 

^From April 2013 a limit will be put on the total amount of benefit that most people aged 16 to 64 can get. This is called a [benefit cap](/benefit-cap "benefit cap").^
table.title: What you'll get

table.body:
Usually, to qualify for Income Support you must:

- be between 16 and [State Pension age](http://pensions-service.direct.gov.uk/en/state-pension-age-calculator/home.asp "Calculating your State Pension age")  
- be on a low income
- work less than 16 hours a week
- live in England, Scotland and Wales - there are different rules for [Northern Ireland](http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/income-support "Northern Ireland Income Support"){:rel="external"}

You don't need a permanent address, eg you can still claim if you sleep rough or live in a hostel or care home.

You might still qualify if you do unpaid volunteer work or go on [parental](/parental-leave "Parental leave") or [paternity leave](/paternityleave "Paternity leave"). Also, if you're a young person in full-time secondary education and one of the following: 

- a parent
- not living with a parent or someone acting as a parent
- at serious risk of abuse or violence
- a refugee learning English

^ Use the [benefits adviser](/benefits-adviser "Benefits adviser") to check your eligibility. ^			

##When you won't qualify 

Usually, you won't qualify if you:

- have savings above £16,000
- need permission to enter the UK
- get Jobseeker's Allowance or Employment and Support Allowance
- are a young person being looked after by a local authority
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
You can apply for Income Support: 

+ by post - send a claim form to your local [Jobcentre Plus](http://los.direct.gov.uk/default.aspx?type=2&lang=en "Find your local Jobcentre Plus"){:rel="external"}
+ by phone

[Download 'Income Support claim form (A1)' you can print out and complete with a pen (PDF, 720KB)](http://www.dwp.gov.uk/advisers/claimforms/a1_print.pdf "Income Support claim form (A1) you can complete on screen"){:rel="external"}  
$D

$C**Jobcentre Plus**  
Telephone: 0800 055 6688  
Textphone: 0800 023 4888  
Welsh telephone line: 0800 012 1888  
Monday to Friday 8am to 6pm  
$C

##What you need to know 

You can claim Income Support for yourself and your partner, if they haven't already made a claim. 

You need to provide details about your income, where you live and who lives with you. 

##Appeal a decision 

You can appeal the decision about your Income Support if you're unhappy with it.
